text:
The eastern Corridor 1 consists predominantly of strongly deformed metasediments and 
 andesitic volcaniclastics, and is bounded in the west by the Childe Harold fault. To the west, 
 Corridor 2 comprises a complex assemblage of mafic and ultramafic volcanic and intrusive 
 rocks, with interlayered iron formation and black shale. Corridor 3 is a relatively narrow, fault

52.text: The following geological summary is taken predominantly from Martyn, 1995a and 1995b.

53.text: The Ida-Barnicoat tenements are situated within the Margaret sector of the Laverton

54.text: Greenstone Belt, in Eastern Goldfields Province of the Archaean Yilgarn Craton. This sector is

55.text: divided into four broadly defined north-south lithostructural corridors or domains,

56.text: distinguished on the basis of lithologic, stratigraphic, structural, metamorphic, and/or magnetic

57.text: features, separated by major strike shear zones.

text:
LOCATION AND ACCESS 
 The Ida-Barnicoat project is situated within the Mt Margaret District of the Mt Margaret 
 Mineral Field, approximately 6km east-northeast of Laverton on the Laverton (SH51-02) 
 1:250,000 sheet and the Laverton (3340) 1:100,000 sheet. The tenements are centered on 
 latitude 28.598º south and longitude 122.442º east. 
 Access is via sealed roads to Laverton, then along White Cliffs Road which runs throught the 
 centre of the tenments. Unsealed roads, station tracks and fence lines provide access 
 throughout the project area. 
 The topography is characterized by low, rounded hills to 200m and extensive low scarps. The 
 climate is semi-arid with occasional flooding caused by cyclonic conditions originating from 
 REGIONAL GEOLOGY 
 The following geological summary is taken predominantly from Martyn, 1995a and 1995b. 
 The Ida-Barnicoat tenements are situated within the Margaret sector of the Laverton 
 Greenstone Belt, in Eastern Goldfields Province of the Archaean Yilgarn Craton. This sector is 
 divided into four broadly defined north-south lithostructural corridors or domains, 
 distinguished on the basis of lithologic, stratigraphic, structural, metamorphic, and/or magnetic 
 features, separated by major strike shear zones.

39.text: John McIntyre. This resulted in regional prospectivity maps and an explanatory report of all

40.text: major nickel localities within the Laverton District. Following this review, the decision was

41.text: made to list the nickel interests as Magma Metals Ltd. Magma Metals Ltd is in the process of

42.text: conducting an extensive review of the nickel, copper and platinum group element exploration

43.text: completed to date over the tenement package. The final submission of this work is expected to

44.text: be available early in the next reporting period.

text:
area were compiled into a single, coherent, basement geology GIS layer. This work included 
 interpretation from regional and detailed aeromagnetic surveying, field mapping and drillhole 
 data. The results for the Ida-Barnicoat area are shown in Figure 3. 
 Compilation of historic surface sample data revealed a strong trend of 1.6km strike along the 
 trace of a regional overturned anticline as mapped by Roland Barsch, 2001 (Metex geological 
 compilation – see below). This included a number of samples over 50ppb Au. 
 To the west of this, a spot rockchip collect by RGC Exploration from small workings returned 
 17.35 ppm Au. Other anomalous rockchips were also collected from quartz veining within the 
 Au analysis results from the surface samples are shown in Figure 4. 
 Shallow drilling targeting the laterite horizon on 400m spaced lines to the north and south of 
 the workings failed to identify mineralization (best values <10ppb Au). However, no drilling 
 appears to have been done in clost proximity to the workings. 
 Regional shallow RAB/Vacuum(?) drilling targeting the laterite horizon was completed by 
 RGC Exploration and Golden State Resources.  This work resulted in two spot anomalies of 
 >100ppb Au within the southern-central portion of E38/1494. Weak anomalism (50 to 
 100ppb) was also intersected along the main surface sample anomaly discussed above. 
 Drilling results are shown in Figure 5. 
 Aeromagnetic Imagery Interpretation 
 Regional aeromagnetic imagery was acquired and interpreted. The western portion of 
 E38/1494 also fell within the area covered by the regional “Laverton Footprint Targeting 
 Study, completed in conjunction with Placer Dome Asia Pacific Ltd. The footprint study 
 included reprocessing and interpretation of detailed aeromagnetic data flown over the 
 neighbouring Laverton Project of Metex Resources Ltd. See Figure 3. 
 Magma Metals Ltd Concurrent Rights Agreement 
 A review of the nickel potential was completed early in the reporting period by consultant, 
 John McIntyre. This resulted in regional prospectivity maps and an explanatory report of all 
 major nickel localities within the Laverton District. Following this review, the decision was 
 made to list the nickel interests as Magma Metals Ltd. Magma Metals Ltd is in the process of 
 conducting an extensive review of the nickel, copper and platinum group element exploration 
 completed to date over the tenement package. The final submission of this work is expected to 
 be available early in the next reporting period. 
 The most prospective ground within the Ida-Barnicoat tenement package occurs within the 
 Hanns Camp area. This target is discussed in detail in Appendix 1.

text:
anomalous and coincident nickel and copper but failed to locate nickel sulphides. However, 
 this drilling did not effectively test the fresh ultramafic rock beneath the shallow anomalies, or 
 a possible southerly plunge projection. 
 A second but smaller thickening of ultramafic unit 2 is present on E38/1494. This possible 
 komatiitic  flow  channel  is  recommended  as  a  target  for  nickel  sulphide  mineralisation  at 
 Hann’s Camp. It could be tested by surface prospecting and shallow RAB drilling across the 
 basal (eastern?) contact of the unit.
